definition:
The *Riemann Xi function*
$$\Xi(s) = \pi^{-\frac{1}{2}s} \Gamma(\frac{1}{2}s) \zeta(s),$$ (where
$\Gamma(s)$ is Euler’s Gamma function and $\zeta(s)$ is the Riemann zeta
function), is the key to the functional equation for the Riemann zeta
function.

Riemann himself used the notation of a lower case xi ($\xi$). The famous
Riemann hypothesis is equivalent to the assertion that all the zeros of
$\xi$ are real, in fact Riemann himself presented his original
hypothesis in terms of that function.

Riemann’s lower case xi is defined as
$$\xi(s) = \frac{1}{2} s(s-1) \Xi(s).$$
